abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though institutional
            development impacts are only modest. Through the
            implementation of the project, a number of lessons have been
            reinforced. The nature of emergency operations requires
            quick responsiveness to infrastructure rehabilitation in
            general, and to investments, and procurement related needs
            in particular, which can be accomplished through a timely
            inventory of crucial investments, designed in light of the
            damage assessment reports, but focused on initial modest
            investments, so as to help mitigate immediate environmental,
            and health hazards effectively, and, create a process which
            can validate rehabilitation needs, as and when presented.
            Therefore, it is not advisable to combine subsequent large
            development investments, with emergency works for
            implementing numerous, though small rehabilitation works,
            since it is difficult enough in the initial prevailing
            environment of capital, and skilled labor constraints. The
            subsequent large investments in water, and wastewater at
            Met'n Barouk, and Ba'albeck required a number of
            extensions, thus delaying project completion, which should
            have otherwise progressed fast, as the nature of emergency
            operations so require. The effectiveness of the Council for
            Development and Reconstruction (CDR) is highlighted, which
            as an autonomous entity, streamlined, and coordinated the
            rehabilitation efforts, and is continuing such a role, given
            that emergencies caused by incidences of external
            hostilities such as in Lebanon, cannot be ruled out in the
            future. However, while emergency works are by nature limited
            to bring about sectoral reforms, the initiation of cost
            recovery, and maintenance costs of new investments could be
            the focus, so that reforms may later rely on the financial
            strength of sectoral institutions.
